Marie Curie: Marie Curie was a pioneering scientist and the first woman to win a Nobel Prize. She made groundbreaking discoveries in the fields of physics and chemistry, and her work laid the foundation for many modern medical treatments. By bringing her back, we could continue her research and potentially make new breakthroughs in the fields of medicine and science.

Mahatma Gandhi: Mahatma Gandhi was a leader in the Indian independence movement and is known for his philosophy of nonviolent resistance. His ideas have inspired movements for civil rights and social justice around the world. By bringing him back, we could learn from his peaceful approach to conflict resolution and apply his principles to contemporary issues.

Charles Darwin: Charles Darwin is best known for his theory of evolution, which revolutionized the way we understand the natural world. By bringing him back, we could continue his research and gain new insights into the diversity of life on Earth.

Albert Einstein: Albert Einstein was a brilliant physicist who developed the theory of relativity and the famous equation E=mc^2. His work has had a profound impact on our understanding of the universe and has led to many technological advancements. By bringing him back, we could continue his research and potentially make new discoveries in the field of physics.

Rosa Parks: Rosa Parks was a civil rights activist who famously refused to give up her seat on a bus, leading to the Montgomery Bus Boycott and the eventual desegregation of public transportation. By bringing her back, we could continue her work towards racial equality and social justice.
